Award.AwardTitle: Dissecting galaxies with bright stars and HII regions
Award.AbstractNarration: This project addresses two long-standing issues concerning the distances and chemical abundances of galaxies: first, the need for a distance indicator that is insensitive to both patchy interstellar dust and to variations in chemical abundances within a galaxy; and second, the need for a better method to infer the chemical compositions of galaxies from the spectra of star forming regions. The PI and co-PI will develop the flux-weighted gravity-luminosity relation (FGLR) technique, through which spectral class B and A supergiant stars can be used as "standard candles" in distance measurements. The techniques employs optical spectroscopy to obtain individual surface gravities, metallicities, temperatures, and thereby luminosities of these stars. They will calibrate this method with observations of the Magellanic Clouds, M31, and IC1316 . With subsequent spectroscopy of supergiant stars and HII regions in an additional sample of target galaxies, they will constrain the evolutionary states of star-forming galaxies from accurate stellar and nebular abundances, study radial abundance gradients in spiral galaxies, and characterize the effect of metallicity on other important techniques used in the extragalactic distance scale. The spectroscopic work rests on a library of detailed model stellar atmospheres, which they will improve and make publicly available. The work will inform strategies appropriate for upcoming generations of large telescopes. A postdoctoral researcher will be supported and mentored under this grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project has been the development and application of a novel method to determine distances and metallicities of galaxies. Measuring distances to galaxies and determining their chemical compositions are two fundamental activities in modern extragalactic astronomy. They help characterizing the physical properties of galaxies and their evolutionary status. Ultimately, these measurements lead to ever stronger constraints on the cosmological parameters of the expanding universe and the history of cosmic chemical enrichment, from the early metal-free universe after the Big Bang to the present-day chemically diversified structure.

The new method uses the quantitative analysis of absorption line spectra of hot massive young supergiant stars, the brightest stars in the universe at visual light. Because of their enormous luminosity, a hundred thousand times the luminosity of the sun, they can be easily detected as individual cosmic beacons in distant galaxies. The analysis of the spectra based on sophisticated theoretical models describing the atmospheres of these stars provides detailed and accurate information about the physical properties of the stars, such as atmospheric temperature, gravitational acceleration and chemical composition. This can be used to predict the intrinsic brightness of these objects and the comparison with the measured brightness observed with the telescope then yields the distance.

One of the great problems in the past with other stellar distance indicators such as Cepheid stars has been the fact that the light emerging from a distant star has to pass through the interstellar medium between the stars in the galaxy observed and in our own Milky Way galaxy, before it reaches the telescope. A correction for this effect, which is called “interstellar reddening and extinction” has always introduced a great uncertainty. For supergiant stars, since we know their intrinsic light distribution precisely from the spectral analysis, these effects can be measured precisely and then corrected for thus eliminating one of the most important uncertainties in the distance determination.

In the project supergiant stars in a sample of galaxies out to 20 million light years distance have been observed with the large telescopes on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, the ESO VLT telescope on Cerro Paranal in Chile and the Carnegie Magellan telescope on Las Campanas in Chile. Using the spectra obtained with these observation the new method was carefully tested and then applied. It was demonstrated that it is indeed possible by this method to determine distances with a precision of 5% or better and to measure the chemical composition, in particular the fraction of heavy elements relative to hydrogen and helium, with an accuracy of 25%.

In this way, the project has very successfully established a new technique to investigate the physical properties of galaxies and their evolution from the birth in the early universe to the present day. It has also established a new accurate method to determine distances to galaxies which will help to measure the Hubble constant and to constrain the physics of the expansion of the accelerated universe with much higher precision. With the next generation of telescopes of the 30m to 40m class this method can be applied to galaxies as far as hundred million light years.
